posts.name: Eren Orhun
posts.cooked: how do we make sure that our elevator is “safe”. we decided to build a 2 stage 2024 5940 style elevator but with 2023 4414 belt drive, what can we do to make it more reliable and make its structure more stiff

posts.name: Drakxii
posts.cooked: Might be helpful to share what you have designed so far, if you have pictures or drawing to show.

posts.name: Eren Orhun
posts.cooked:
Ekran görüntüsü 2025-01-14 001828 370×748 44.7 KB We decided to make the elevator without the top tubes (similar to5940 2024) to maximize our capacity to reach l4

Ekran görüntüsü 2025-01-14 001828 370×748 44.7 KB

Ekran görüntüsü 2025-01-14 001828 370×748 44.7 KB

Attention to detail. Perfectly set up the rigging in cad, because this will make your life easier. Perfectly straight runs, minimal fleet angle, and proper spool alignment help. Ensure the main elevator body is supported by diagonal beams and the cross-braces on each stage are not subject to bending. Take this over to manufacturing too, as thousands of an inch matter when there’s a lot of moving parts, so improving tolerances significantly reduces stackup.

posts.name: Anand Rajamani
posts.cooked:
erenorhun:

We decided to make the elevator without the top tubes (similar to5940 2024) to maximize our capacity to reach l4

Well, first of all, I’d add these back. You can offset them and inch away from the elevator but they are massively helpful in creating stiffness. Your travel will be limited by how much your stages overlap, not the existence of support bars. You’ll want at least 8" of overlap to be perfectly safe, but you can get away with 4-6" with testing.

Similarly you’ll want big diagonal braces running from the top of the elevator (or like 2/3 the way up) to your chassis to give it some triangular support.

Your carriage bearing blocks should be spaced as far apart as possible to maximize stability. I’d also ramp up the fillets on your corner gussets. Those can be made thicker to resist tearing at the holes too.

posts.name: Anya Chopra
posts.cooked:
erenorhun:

We decided to make the elevator without the top tubes (similar to5940 2024)

Are you running a crossrail or anything? I know the 5940 2024 elevator had issues with popping out. It did have a good amount of weight on the elevator as well but the open top def did not help (wasn’t super stiff to keep the sides spread apart and the carriage would pop out). We made a clone of that robot for the off-season and had the carriage pop out a few times

This was one of the other types of elevator pop outs we experienced

posts.name: Trevor Dayal (he/him)
posts.cooked:
FRCDesign.org has some great elevator examples, so I’d recommend referencing them.

Specifically, the 1678 2023 elevator probably matches your design goals.

erenorhun:

without the top tubes (similar to5940 2024)

Hi, I’m your friendly neighborhood Bread Mentor. Don’t do this. Just a courtesy of your friendly neighborhood Bread Mentor!

posts.name: Eren Orhun
posts.cooked: We were planning to use an arm/pivot mechanism on the smallest frame on our elevator, we also planned to have it as low as possible but in 1678’s design the pivot of the intake is on top. It may be a problem for us during deep climb.

posts.name: Eren Orhun
posts.cooked: Do we need to add those tubes “especially” on top or is it ok if we add them like 1678’s 2023 robot but lower

posts.name: Morgan Withers
posts.cooked:
For our 2024 elevator we made something called banner rails which were just .09 sheets of aluminum in between the stages for the bearings to run on.

To prevent mast bowing we made aluminum braces at the corner of the mast.

Check out our 2024 build thread for more information.

link_counts.title: Team SCREAM Open Alliance | Team 4522 and 4766 | Build Thread 2024

posts.cooked: You need the tubes on top. The tube on top, whether directly on top or offset from the back, is the only thing preventing your elevator from bending inwards. Without it, your elevator is just 3ft cantilever beams which are incredibly weak. 1678 2023 offset the top tubes so they won’t get in the way of carriage travel, but still perform the same support role.

posts.name: Eren Orhun
posts.cooked: One of my favorite robots from 2024, can you show a detailed picture of the banner rails and the braces that prevents mast bowing, also did you had any issues with stiffness of your elevator

posts.name: Morgan Withers
posts.cooked:
I took some screenshots from out CAD which of both our banner rails and bracing. Our CAD is also linked in our build thread from last year.

We went through about four iterations of the elevator throughout the season. After integrating our climber into our elevator after our first event we had many issues with the bearings becoming derailed and the masts bowing out but after rebuilding after our week four event we found solutions to our problems. We had no elevator issues for the entirety of worlds even with it getting rammed into the stage several times throughout.

We plan on keeping banner rails and corner bracing in our elevator we are designing this year.

posts.name: Anand Rajamani
posts.cooked: You can probably put it a few inches down from the top, but the closer the better. Really depends on what you’re doing overall.
